docs.snippet: In Madrid, New Delhi, Tel Aviv, Frankfurt and Buenos Aires, airports were silent and nearly empty. In Rome, Amsterdam, Zurich and Belgrade, harried travelers vied for tickets on crowded trains. In Panama City, a pilot lay down in front of a jetliner...
docs.lead_paragraph: In Madrid, New Delhi, Tel Aviv, Frankfurt and Buenos Aires, airports were silent and nearly empty. In Rome, Amsterdam, Zurich and Belgrade, harried travelers vied for tickets on crowded trains. In Panama City, a pilot lay down in front of a jetliner to make sure it could not take off.
docs.abstract: effect of stoppage discussed; empty airline terminals at Kennedy Internatl Airport and Schiphol Airport (Amsterdam) and grounded jetliners at GB's Heathrow Airport illus

headline.main: Protest Empties Airports From Tel Aviv to Maine; Uncertainty About Flights Poses Major Problems for Domestic Travelers -- Kennedy Traffic Cut a Fourth

docs.snippet: ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 29 -- This year for first time in 111 years, the United States Embassy, on orders from Washington, scheduled no Fourth of July party for Paraguayan Government officials.
docs.lead_paragraph: ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 29 -- This year for first time in 111 years, the United States Embassy, on orders from Washington, scheduled no Fourth of July party for Paraguayan Government officials.
docs.abstract: US Embassy in Asunction, Paraguay, cancels 4th of July celebration for first time in 111 yrs; says cancellation exhibits US's anger with Paraguayan officials who are allegedly protecting and/or deeply involved in several large internatl narcotic rings using US as conduit for narcotics from Eur and other areas

headline.main: PARAGUAY ANGERS U.S. OVER DRUGS; 2 Wanted Men Said to Be Protected by Officials

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, July 9 (Reuters) -- The Roman Catholic Church in Latin America, raising its voice to protest maltreatment of political and other prisoners and to demand social reforms, is heading for clashes with rightist Governments in at least five...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, July 9 (Reuters) -- The Roman Catholic Church in Latin America, raising its voice to protest maltreatment of political and other prisoners and to demand social reforms, is heading for clashes with rightist Governments in at least five nations.
docs.abstract: RC Ch in Latin Amer may clash with rightist Govts as increasing number of bishops, priests and nuns protest maltreatment of pol prisoners and demand sweeping soc and econ reforms; such ch activism, which has resulted in arrests of many members of ch orgns, is also causing growing dispute between progressive and conservative factions within ch itself; ch response to pol situation in Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay, Bolivia and Paraguay detailed; priest illus with slum dwellers, Buenos Aires

headline.main: Church in Latin America May Clash With Rightist Governments

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: AMERICAN NATIONS AND WESTERN HEMISPHERE POSSESSIONS

docs.snippet: SAO PAULO, Brazil -- Is South America's 1972 economic bag half-full or half-empty now that the year is half over?
docs.lead_paragraph: SAO PAULO, Brazil -- Is South America's 1972 economic bag half-full or half-empty now that the year is half over?
docs.abstract: NY Times survey finds Brazil's econ surge gathered momentum in 1st half of '72, far outpacing all other repubs in Latin Amer; inflation is steady at about 20% for yr, low by Brazilian standards, and GNP is estimated to exceed 10% in net growth; less pleasant aspects include fact that only 5% of 100 million people benefited from 5 yrs of econ growth, rapid deterioration of environment and illegal status of labor unions, which keeps wages low; over a billion dollars of foreign investment and bank loans continue to pour into Brazil each yr

headline.main: Latin-American Economies Take Mixed Course; Brazil's Trade Rises but Other Nations Experience Woes Latin Economies On a Mixed Course

byline.original: By H. J. MAIDENBERGSpecial to The New York Times
